desc: STAT5B encodes a transcription factor involved in the JAK signaling cascade. Mutations and copy number alterations of STAT5B are found in leukemias, lymphomas and breast cancers.

gene.name: signal transducer and activator of transcription 5B

desc: Signal transducer and activator of transcription 5B (STAT5B) is a transcription factor that is activated by cytokine and growth factors including Interleukin 2 and 4 (IL2, IL4), Colony stimulating factor 1 (CSF1), and different growth hormones (PMID:15313458, 9630227). It is phosphorylated by Janus kinase (JAK) kinases, resulting in dimerization and nuclear translocation (PMID:25527793). STAT5B regulates the development and differentiation of tissues and cell types including the mammary gland, hepatocytes, erythrocytes, platelets, and B-cells and T-cells (PMID:15711548, 23773921, 8961260, 8906870, 18347089, 16418296). In cancer, STAT5B signaling is important for tumor progression, resistance, and transformation in various cancers including prostate cancer, breast cancer, myeloproliferative neoplasms, and leukemias (PMID:22234689, 23660011, 18508994). Activating STAT5B mutations are found in large granular lymphocytic leukemia and subtypes of lymphomas (PMID:23596048, 25586472, 24972766). STAT5B is also found in rare translocations with RARA in cases of acute promyelocytic leukemia (PMID:22749039). Copy number alternation have been identified in breast cancer samples (PMID:25470049).
